body_raw: The only way I can show  $$\cos(20^\circ)\cos(30^\circ)\cos(40^\circ)=\cos^2(10^\circ)\cos(50^\circ)$$ stinks of sweat and brute force: If $\cos(10^\circ)=x$ then using $\cos(a+b) = \cos a \cos b - \sin a \sin b$ and $\cos^2 + \sin^2 = 1$ you get $$ \cos(20^\circ) = 2x^2-1\\ \cos(30^\circ) = 4x^3-3x \\ \cos(40^\circ) = 8x^4-8x^2+1\\ \cos(80^\circ) = 128x^8-256x^6+160x^4-32x^2+1 $$ Then  $$ \sin(10^\circ) = 128x^8-256x^6+160x^4-32x^2+1 $$ and using $\sin (a+b) = \sin(a) \cos(b) + \cos a \sin b$ and $\sin(30^\circ)=\frac12$ you get $$ \sin(20^\circ)= 256x^9 -512x^7+320x^5-64x^3+2x \\ \cos(50^\circ)=(2x^2-1)(4x^x-3x) - \frac12(256x^9 -512x^7+320x^5-64x^3+2x)\\ \cos(50^\circ) = -128x^9+256x^7-152x^5+22x^3+2x $$ Now that we have all the needed values of cosines, we have to prove that $$ (2x^2-1)(4x^x-3x)(8x^4-8x^2+1)=x^2(-128x^9+256x^7-152x^5+22x^3+2x)\\ 64x^9-144x^7+112x^5-34x^3+3x=-128x^{11}+256x^9-152x^7+22x^5+2x^3 $$ The tool we have is that $\cos(30^\circ) = \frac{\sqrt{3}}{2}$ so $$x^3=\frac{\sqrt{3}/2+3x}{4} $$ We now have to use that replace the highest power of $x$ by 2 powers lower; for example, using  $$x^{11} = \frac{3x^9}{4} + \frac{\sqrt{3}}{8}x^8$$ I had to do this replacement trick thirteen times (seven on the right side and six on the left) before I came to  $$ -x^3 + \frac{\sqrt{3}x^2}{2} + \frac{3x}{4} = -x^3 + \frac{\sqrt{3}x^2}{2} + \frac{3x}{4} $$ And we come to the original question -- there has got to be an easier way to show this!
